Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: The latest issue of the law review journal sits on my desk, its crisp pages promising insights into evolving legal theories. As a judge, I know I must stay current—my rulings depend on it. I glance at the clock, calculating how much I can read before the polling station opens. Today is election day, and as a voter, I’m expected to bring valid identification. I check my wallet: my driver’s license is there, but my passport and other IDs are at home. I could fetch them later, but the thought nags at me—what if I get caught up in court business or the journal’s articles and forget? The pressure mounts. My judicial duty urges me to immerse myself in the journal, to be the best judge I can be. Yet, the civic responsibility of voting tugs at me, reminding me that my participation matters. I feel torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my attention, each unwilling to wait. I stand at my desk, journal in hand, wallet in the other, uncertain which expectation to meet first.
